The Center envisions a gender-equitable world in which girls and boys experience safe, healthy, and empowered transitions to adulthood. title: Presidency Youth Climate Champion (PYCC) – COP31: A National Call for Young Climate Leaders
summary: The Australian Government is calling for Expressions of Interest (EOIs) from young Australians ready to shape global climate action. The position is embedded within the COP31 Presidency, enabling the selected candidate to bring youth perspectives into the heart of climate negotiations. With COP31 hosted by T rkiye and Australia serving as President of Negotiations, the PYCC will contribute to a process that directly influences climate policies shaping the futures of young people for decades to come. The role is designed to create space, voice, and influence for youth without placing responsibility for negotiating outcomes on young people themselves. The PYCC will be supported by the COP31 Presidency team and collaborate with national, regional, and international partners. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(127); }); Key Responsibilities 1. Meaningful Youth Participation The PYCC will use their position to ensure children and youth can participate fully and safely across COP31-related processes. The aim is to create structured pathways for youth to contribute policy ideas and generate tangible outcomes. 2. Amplifying Youth Voices A major function of the role is to elevate the priorities of diverse youth communities including First Nations and Pacific youth within the Presidency and broader UNFCCC discussions. This may include presenting youth-led statements, sharing stocktake insights, and convening dialogues with global decision-makers. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(128); }); 3. Systems, Access, and Support The PYCC will advocate for proper safeguarding, accessibility, logistics, and resourcing to enable inclusive participation. Capacity-Building The PYCC will help expand access to climate education, negotiation skills, and UNFCCC learning tools. title: Paul D. Coverdell Fellows Program: Graduate Funding for Returned Peace Corps Volunteers
summary: The Paul D. Coverdell Fellows Program offers Returned Peace Corps Volunteers (RPCVs) a unique pathway to continue their service while pursuing graduate degrees, professional certificates, and advanced training across the United States. Designed to recognise the global experience, adaptability, and community-driven skills that Volunteers gain abroad, the program provides financial assistance and hands-on professional opportunities that strengthen careers and support underserved communities. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(119); }); About the Paul D. Coverdell Fellows Program The Coverdell Fellows Program is an educational fellowship that supports RPCVs seeking to deepen their impact through further study. Fellows receive a combination of tuition reductions, scholarships, stipends, assistantships, or other forms of financial aid. Beyond academic support, the program keeps RPCVs connected to the Peace Corps mission by placing them in internships in the United States that address locally identified needs. This blend of education, service, and professional advancement makes the program one of the most valuable benefits available to Volunteers after returning home. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(127); }); Why Become a Coverdell Fellow? Financial Support Partner universities offer fellows a range of benefits, from partial tuition reductions to full scholarships and paid assistantships. This makes advanced education more affordable and accessible for RPCVs across different fields. Hands-On Service Each Fellow completes an internship with a U.S.-based organisation, strengthening their applied skills while serving local communities. These internships align with Peace Corps values, ensuring that participants continue to support community priorities. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(128); }); Professional Development Fellows build leadership skills, gain practical workplace experience, and expand their networks. Many institutions integrate internships with coursework, offering meaningful opportunities to connect learning with real-world problem-solving. Extending the Peace Corps Mission By sharing their international experiences in classrooms and local communities, Fellows help fulfil the Peace Corps third goal: to promote a better understanding of other peoples among Americans. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(129); }); Choice and Flexibility With more than 150 partner universities across the United States, RPCVs can pursue degrees in social work, public health, education, international affairs, environmental studies, and many more disciplines. Federal Hiring Advantage RPCVs may qualify for extended noncompetitive eligibility for federal jobs up to three years after service, depending on agency discretion if they enrol soon after returning. Eligibility Criteria RPCVs maintain lifetime eligibility for the Coverdell Fellows Program if they meet one of the following: ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(130); }); Completed a full Peace Corps tour or received completion of service status. Were medically separated. Received interrupted service due to circumstances beyond their control. Completed at least 12 months of Peace Corps Response or Advancing Health Professionals service within a 24-month period. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(131); }); Volunteers who resigned or were administratively separated are not eligible unless they previously earned eligibility through earlier service. Questions about eligibility can be directed to the Peace Corps Office of University Programs. How to Apply Applications to the Coverdell Fellows Program are handled directly by partner universities. The Peace Corps does not manage or decide individual admissions. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(132); }); Prospective applicants should: Contact coordinators at participating universities. Request detailed program and application information. Follow each school s deadlines, requirements, and instructions carefully. Prepare necessary materials such as transcripts, test scores (if required), and a signed Description of Service (DOS). Many universities allow RPCVs to apply online, even while still abroad. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(133); }); Application Deadline Because each partner institution manages its own application cycle, deadlines vary by program . RPCVs should check the specific due dates for every university they plan to apply to. Why This Program Matters For RPCVs, the Coverdell Fellows Program is more than an academic opportunity it is a chance to build on global service, strengthen local communities, and gain meaningful professional experience. Whether through public health work, educational initiatives, or community development, Fellows continue to advance the core principles of the Peace Corps while preparing for impactful careers.
